results.title: Love
results.creator_credit: Pat Hunder, Garry Dunstan, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and It's About Time
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Not suitable for adults”.
This episode focuses on teenage reactions to love and relationships. Through mini dramatisations, issues such as crushes on teachers, how to be attractive to the opposite sex, romantic fiction and sex-role stereotyping, are examined in a humorous manner. This program aims at validating the experiences of teenagers rather than offering any concrete solutions.

results.title: Lousy Little Sixpence
results.creator_credit: Alec Morgan, Gerald Bostock and Sixpence Productions
results.brief_description: Archival film footage, photographs and the memories of Aboriginal elders weave a moving account of the lives of Aboriginal people and their struggle in the 1930s against the Aborigines Protection Board.

constellations_other.name: Setting the record straight
constellations_other.description: For too long, the history of Australia was only told in mainstream films through a white lens. First Nations people have used the camera as a means of truth-telling and setting the record straight for decades.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Alec Morgan, Gerald Bostock and Sixpence Productions
results.description: In 1909 the N.S.W. Aborigines Protection Board planned to break up Aboriginal communities by forcibly removing children and hiring them out to white “masters”. Archival film footage, photographs and the memories of Aboriginal elders weave a moving account of the lives of Aboriginal people and their struggle in the 1930s against the Aborigines Protection Board. Appearing in the film: Margaret Tucker, Bill Reid, Geraldine Briggs, Flo Caldwell, Violet Shea. Narrated by Chicka Dixon.
description_for_label: In 1909 the N.S.W. Aborigines Protection Board planned to break up Aboriginal communities by forcibly removing children and hiring them out to white “masters”. Archival film footage, photographs and the memories of Aboriginal elders weave a moving account of the lives of Aboriginal people and their struggle in the 1930s against the Aborigines Protection Board. Appearing in the film: Margaret Tucker, Bill Reid, Geraldine Briggs, Flo Caldwell, Violet Shea. Narrated by Chicka Dixon.

results.title: Loup
results.creator_credit: Northern Metropolitan Institute of TAFE and Kerreen Ely-Harper
results.brief_description:
Loup showcases the talents of the Arts Education dance group students (with disabilities) from NMIT (Northern Melbourne Institute of TAFE). Loup, full of zest and the notion: to dance; to flee; to leap; to burst, lit up the dancers’ desire to devise creative expression in open spaces. In Loup, commemorating the year of the life of the ocean, the dancers, through improvised movements, developed their vision towards a common destination - the sea. Its openness and vastness, power and force depict the energy of freedom that eliminates all barriers. Barriers that may arise from disabilities are suddenly irrelevant.
Loup was filmed at the Jawbone site in the Wetlands in Williamstown. This is a protected conservation area and is used as a metaphor to represent the dancers’ expectation of a safe and open space in which to be, and express freely.
After a decade of regular dance workshops and performances, the artists naturally progressed into a new stage ‘ exploration of dance with media. Creative camera work captured the integrity of their movements. This art form expanded the dimensions of the discipline much practiced by the dancers. At the same time it enabled the documentation of the works thus creating new resources in the field.
Loup, since its production in 1998, has been screened at national and international festivals and community events.

results.title: Loulou [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Action Films, Gaumont-British Instructional, Klaus Hellwig, Yves Gasser and Maurice Pialat
results.brief_description: A middle-class woman (Isabelle Huppert) leaves her safe long-term relationship with her boss (Guy Marchand) for good sex and a socially-marginal existence with a roughly handsome unemployed working-class man (Gerard Depardieu). Shot largely in long handheld takes, the film posits sex as a force that shatters not only class allegiances and established social patterns but even the order represented by conventional narrative structures. Eliciting spontaneous and improvised performances from his actors, Pialat blends a loosely told love story with an acute social observation of the sexual and social mores of France in the seventies. The characters’ actions and behaviours are presented straightforwardly without moralising, enabling an open-ended exploration of the way class differences play out in power relations between the sexes.

results.title: Louise Drouin: veterinarian
results.creator_credit: Louise Spence, ONF | NFB and Margaret Wescott
results.brief_description: A portrait of a country veterinarian, working mother, and partner in a thriving practice. In the film, Dr. Drouin shares many facets of her life: at work in her surgery, making “house calls” that take her over a hundred miles from home, and rare moments of relaxation with her husband and child. Articulate and forthright, she talks about the joys and sorrows of being a veterinarian, and how she balances the demands of a busy profession with those of raising a family.

results.title: Louisbourg [French version]
results.creator_credit: Tom Daly, ONF | NFB and Albert Kish
results.brief_description: Shows the restoration of the Fortress of Louisbourg on Cape Breton Island. The fort, originally built by King Louis XV to protect French possessions in the French Colonial era, is considered to be the largest historical site and dig in North America. A methodological film showing techniques of research involved in reconstructing some of the main buildings.

results.title: Louis Nowra
results.brief_description: Emerging from the last decade as one of Australia’s leading dramatists, Louis Nowra discusses why his plays have been described as “anti-naturalistic”.

results.title: Louis James hates school
results.creator_credit: Learning Corporation of America and Paul Fillinger
results.brief_description: Louis James hated school, and never learned to read or spell. All he wanted to do was get a job and make a lot of money. Into the rubbish bin went his books and he headed to town to find a job. He applied as a pilot for a skywriting company but he soon found that his spelling mistakes were too big and too apparent. His job hunting went from the embarrassingly bad to the horrendous as the determined dropout discovers for himself the real value of reading and spelling, whether in school or out. Animated film.

results.title: Louis IX, Roi, Chevalier et Saint = Louis IX, king, knight and saint
results.brief_description:
The eve of the XIIIth century marks the revival of royal power. In France, Louis IX models himself on Charlemagne and, just like his illustrious predecessor, has a chapel, La Sainte Chapelle, built to symbolise his authority and his role as a intermediary between man and God. During this period, Saint Louis participates in two Crusades in the Orient. Although a failure, the Crusades reveal to the Europeans a world much wider and more diverse than they ever imagined. With better boats, stirring and maps, Europeans are able to set off to far flung parts of the globe and bring back marvellous tales and exotic products. This is a time of discovery and optimism, reflected in a certain estheticism in art and where the beautiful primes over the demonstrative. The XIIIth century sees the creative impulse shift from France to Italy with its soaring class of merchants and bankers.

Credits: Director, Roland Darbois ; writers, Roger Stephane, Roland Darbois, photography, Roland Dantigny.
Cast: Narrated by Georges Duby.
